{"title": "Monster Hunter Freedom 2", "title_search": "monster hunter freedom 2", "title_keyword": "monster hunter freedom 2", "url": "https://www.metacritic.com/game/monster-hunter-freedom-2/", "summary": "The hunt-or-be-hunted adventure continues with more content and options than ever before. Multiplayer cooperative battles for up to four friends via wireless ad hoc mode foster team building and strategy for the ultimate battle of man vs. beast. With the addition of infrastructure functionality, players will now be able to download even more content and quests. {"title": "Brian Lara International Cricket 2007", "title_search": "brian lara international cricket 2007", "title_keyword": "brian lara international cricket 2007", "url": "https://www.metacritic.com/game/brian-lara-international-cricket-2007/", "summary": "(Also known as \"Ricky Ponting International Cricket 2007\")  Brian Lara International Cricket 2007 expands the series' trademark fluid, dynamic gameplay mechanics to deliver a thoroughly entertaining and competitive game that captures all the tension, skill and intensity of world-class international cricket. Thanks to the official ICC Cricket World Cup 2007 content, Brian Lara International Cricket 2007 features licensed players, including world cricket stars Andrew Flintoff, Ricky Ponting, Mahendra Dhoni, Muttiah Muralitharan and of course, Brian Lara himself. In addition to players, the game leads with a dedicated ICC Cricket World Cup 2007 mode featuring all the official teams, stadia, kits and equipment of the tournament. Further modes include a fully licensed ICC Champions' Trophy competition and exhibition matches including One Day Games, Test Matches and exciting 20-over run fests. When you want to get competitive for real, Brian Lara International Cricket 2007 will deliver with online competitive play on PC (LAN and online) and Xbox Live. BLIC 2007 adds extra depth to the series' complete batting, bowling and fielding experience whilst retaining its trademark accessible playability. The batting play sees the introduction of subtle edges, sweepshots and the ability to use your feet to dance down wicket and smash the ball over the boundary for six. Bowling sees an improved set of delivery types, thanks to changes in the way the ball swings in the air and reacts off the pitch, showcasing Shane Warne's huge variation of spinning deliveries and Steve Harmison's raw pace and even reverse swing as the ball degrades. In Fielding, there's a new reflex-testing slip catch system and players can now be run out at both ends and be stumped by alert wicket keepers. [Codemasters]", "genre": ["Cricket"], "metascore": "71", "critic_reviews": 7, "user_score": "9.1", "user_reviews": 8, "release_date": "2007-03-23", "images": ["https://www.metacritic.com/a/img/catalog/provider/6/3/6-1-78478-13.jpg", "https://www.metacritic.com/a/img/catalog/provider/6/3/6-1-78478-13.jpg"], "video": null, "video_thumbnail": null, "video_type": null, "sentiment": "Mixed or average", "must_play": false, "crew": ["Jonathan Agnew (Cast: Self - Commentator)", "Ian Bishop (Cast: Self - Commentator)", "Mahendra Singh Dhoni (Cast: Self)", "Andrew Flintoff (Cast: Self)", "David Gower (Cast: Self - Commentator)", "Tony Greig (Cast: Self - Commentator)", "Brian Lara (Cast: Self)", "Bill Lawry (Cast: Self - Commentator)", "Brett Lee (Cast: Self)", "Muttiah Muralitharan (Cast: Self)", "Monty Panesar (Cast: Self)", "Ricky Ponting (Cast: Self)", "Oliver Johnson (Sound: game sound designer)", "Philip Roberts (Editorial: additional editor)", "Stephen Bennett (lead programmer)"], "countries": ["Europe", "Australia", "North America"], "companies": ["Codemasters (Developer)", "Codemasters (Publisher)"], "platforms": ["PlayStation 2", "Xbox 360", "PC"], "rating": null}

{"title": "Crush, Crumble & Chomp!", "title_search": "crush crumble  chomp", "title_keyword": "crush crumble  chomp", "url": "https://www.metacritic.com/game/crush-crumble-and-chomp/", "summary": "Breathe fire, terrorize cities, snack on a horrified populace, and further develop your villainous personality. CRUSH, CRUMBLE, and CHOMP!\r Is there a particular city against which you crave to wreak revenge? Do you have a grudge against the Golden Gate Bridge? Lunch on San Francisco, then. Can't control your burning desire to consume the Pentagon? Dine on Washington, D.C. Fed up with cheap imports? Tokyo, perhaps. Do you hunger for the Big Apple? Munch on New York.\r Be the deadly amphibian who longs to leave trails of poisonous nuclear pollution; simultaneously smash street cars with a single blow of your scaly tail, lunch on helpless humans, and radiate a ray of death from your malevolent eye.\r Or would you like to be, perhaps, not even of the fallible flesh but, rather, of horrendously heartless steel? A lifeless, but life-like, mechanical gizmo preprogrammed by zero population growth professionals for the destruction of all things earthly.\r If you were a giant winged creature, think of the aerial attacks you could make on the terrified but tasty tidbits beneath you.\r Take on the persona of any of six demonic beasties (even more for those who have a disk). Select from four mouth-watering metropoli and five different objectives--over 100 possible scenarios, complete with graphic mayhem and the resounding thunder of your monsterly presence, await your beastly appetite.\r But wait! The National Guard is out to get you. The local police are sworn to your destruction. Even as you read this, a secret weapon is being readied against you by mad and skillful scientists. Are you truly prepared to face helicopters, tanks, artillery, and more, driven by those who are literally dying to get at you?\r Sooner or later, humanity will triumph... maybe. Or maybe vengeance will be yours.\r - Graphics. Computer-generated metroplis. (Apple and Atari use high-resolution color)\r - Sound\r - Real time\r - You are the villain\r - Six monsters, four cities, five game objectives--over 100 possible scenarios\r - For ages 10 through adult\r - Complexity: Intermediate\r - Playing time: 10 minutes to 1 hour\r - For one monster", "genre": ["Turn-Based Strategy"], "metascore": 0, "critic_reviews": 0, "user_score": 0, "user_reviews": 0, "release_date": null, "images": ["https://www.metacritic.com/a/img/catalog/provider/6/3/6-1-79359-13.jpg", "https://www.metacritic.com/a/img/catalog/provider/6/3/6-1-79359-13.jpg"], "video": null, "video_thumbnail": null, "video_type": null, "sentiment": null, "must_play": null, "crew": null, "countries": ["North America"], "companies": ["Epyx (Publisher)", "Epyx (Developer)"], "platforms": ["PC"], "rating": null}

{"title": "Backpacker (1995)", "title_search": "backpacker 1995", "title_keyword": "backpacker 1995", "url": "https://www.metacritic.com/game/backpacker-1995/", "summary": "You have decided to travel around the world. But there's one problem. You don't have enough money to make the entire journey! \"Everything will work out,\" you think while you fill in your passport and transfer all your money to your international credit care. With your rucksack as your only companion, you set off for the airport.  The world awaits you...  So begin your journey. Your goal is to travel around the world and return home in one piece. If you think it sounds easy, just remember that just like real life, things are not always as easy as they seem... You're on your own from here.  BackPacker is different each time you play. You decide which route around the world you want to take and can you afford the ticket? We'll decide what kind of work you want to do once you reach your destination to earn enough money to continue your travels. Even if there are more places to visit and more things to do in the real world, you'll find that BackPacker will always have a surprise waiting for you... new experiences and challenges every time you play, and just as in the real world, remember it's fun to travel with friends. Visit many towns and villages, and travel through deep forests, forgotten ruins and hidden dungeons. During your journey, you will have to battle fearsome creatures, avoid deadly traps and resolve many riddles, but fortunately you will meet friendly and weird characters ready to help you in your quest.  Features: _ Languages : FRENCH, ENGLISH. _ Explore many interior and exterior places, from towns and villages to forests, ruins, mines and dungeons. _ Resolve many riddles, and use your mind as well as your sword. _ Drink mimic potions to take your enemies appearance and fool them. _ Battle fearsome monsters, like Dwarf Shadows, Chelobs, Orcs, and many more. _ Use your environment, switches and mechanisms to enable or disable traps, open doors and find secret passages. Use them, but use them judiciously. _ Level up your equipment in shops: buy powerful swords, tough armours, bows, magical scrolls and potions. _ Meet many friendly and funny characters who will guide you through your quest. _ Beware of poison, fire and ice threats. {"title": "Blur", "title_search": "blur", "title_keyword": "blur", "url": "https://www.metacritic.com/game/blur/", "summary": "Blur is a new style of powered-up racing. The game drops players into heart-pumping racing action with 20 cars on a track all targeting the finish line and battling each other as they trade paint and collect intense power-ups, including the ability to blast other cars out of the way with huge bursts of energy, boost their speed, and more. Gamers can use offensive and defensive attacks as they battle for the lead and careen through real-world track locations ranging from L.A. and San Francisco to the streets of Hackney, UK and the treacherous roads of Barcelona, Spain. Beyond the action-packed racing filled with fast curves, sneaky alternate routes, hair-raising jumps and fully realized damage models that provide for spectacular crashes, Blur\u2019s narrative is presented through Bizarre\u2019s new community-based interface, reaching far beyond the game itself. This unique story-driving social network evolves dynamically as players compete in different races, make new friends, rivals and fans, and connect with other racers both in-game and in real life. Looking beyond Blur's single player story, gamers can engage in competitive and team-based multiplayer races with up to 20 players online, or on a single console via 4-player split-screen. Bizarre has also introduced Blur\u2019s original social gaming experience - Custom Groups, where anyone can create unique multiplayer modes based on their favorite ways to play the game. These new modes are immediately shared through Blur\u2019s social network, expanding the game in ways that are only limited by the gaming community\u2019s creativity. [Activision]", "genre": ["Auto Racing"], "metascore": "82", "critic_reviews": 78, "user_score": "8.3", "user_reviews": 122, "release_date": "2010-05-25", "images": ["https://www.metacritic.com/a/img/catalog/provider/6/3/6-1-623661-13.jpg", "https://www.metacritic.com/a/img/catalog/provider/6/3/6-1-623661-13.jpg"], "video": null, "video_thumbnail": null, "video_type": null, "sentiment": "Generally favorable", "must_play": false, "crew": null, "countries": ["Europe", "Australia", "Japan", "North America", "Korea"], "companies": ["Bizarre Creations (Developer)", "Activision (Publisher)"], "platforms": ["Xbox 360", "PC", "PlayStation 3"], "rating": "E10+"}

{"title": "2 Minute Mysteries: Garage", "title_search": "2 minute mysteries garage", "title_keyword": "2 minute mysteries garage", "url": "https://www.metacritic.com/game/2-minute-mysteries-garage/", "summary": "2 Minute Mysteries is a series of short interactive mysteries in which you take on the role of the detectives and must solve the crimes. {"title": "King's Cup (2008)", "title_search": "kings cup 2008", "title_keyword": "kings cup 2008", "url": "https://www.metacritic.com/game/kings-cup-2008/", "summary": "Get some friends together, grab your iPhone or iPod Touch, a glass and your favorite beverages to drink. King's Cup is a variation of the age-old card game which draws on the magic of Quartz Core Animations to transform the experience to a whole new level!  Each player simply selects a card at random from the virtual deck. The card is then revealed indicating an action to take along with a fun animation displayed in brilliant colors using the iPhone or iPod Touch's media player to demonstrate that action! With integrated rules for each card, players of all experience levels can participate.   King's Cup is a full screen guide to a great time. Players test their physical and mental reflexes as they take turns following the actions on the cards that players pick. Need to answer an incoming call, or text message? Not a problem, King's Cup saves your games, remembering which cards have been played while your iPhone flawlessly handles your communications so you can pick up the action right where you left off! Whether with a small group of friends or while having a beer at your college fraternity party, King's Cup will surely liven things up. {"title": "Poker Stacks", "title_search": "poker stacks", "title_keyword": "poker stacks", "url": "https://www.metacritic.com/game/poker-stacks/", "summary": "Gem Swapping meet your new dance partner, Video Poker!  New Version - Casual Untimed Mode.  --------------------  What do you get when you cross Bejeweled with Video Poker?  You get a fun and original match style puzzle game. Poker Stacks.  Yes, someone has finally successfully mutated Gem Swapping Games like Puzzle Quest with the great game of Poker. Others have tried but now a truly fun and original game is here. The next generation of Puzzle Game now on your iPhone or iPod Touch.   Poker Stacks is based on games like Bejeweled 2, Tetris, or Bubbles and builds on them in that you are trying to match real poker hands to clear the board and move to the next level.   You do not need to know or be good at poker to love this game. You just have to be comfortable with the poker hands, and we can even teach you those...  If you love games like Trism, Fuzzle, Poker Dice, Glyph, or Aurora Feint and/or you enjoy Video Poker or Texas Hold 'Em you have to give Poker Stacks a try.   Features ---------------------- * Clean attractive game board and animations that don't over distract from game play. * 3 Game Modes with 2 Difficulty settings * Advancing levels of play with greater challenges. * Help system  * Sound on/off - And listen to your own music. * High Score System. * Saves Game Progress on Exit - Continue after a call or if you need to pause.   Game Play ---------------------- It is suggested that you read the help screen for more information before playing.   The idea is to select poker hands to clear the board so that all of the remaining card tiles fall into the given bottom rows(arrows on the side) before the time runs out. Advancing levels bring new challenges.   Slide your finger over up to 5 cards to select the poker hands. Order isn't important so straights dont have to be in order and pairs dont have to be right next to each other. Tiles not directly involved in the hand's scoring,'kicker cards', will remain on the board. Bigger hands mean bigger points.   You can also swap a piece exactly once with an adjacent piece between each hand played. The back will then turn blue showing the swapped pieces are frozen in place.   Finally, you can slide pieces vertically into open spaces. Gravity will pull them down if it can.   Those are the rules, its up to you to figure out the best strategies.   Who has the high score on your device?  What they're saying ----------------------  "it is fantastic!!!!!! ... Seriously, this game is great! ...  In all, it is a great game that requires a good deal of thought and strategy. It is a good deal of fun in the short term and, I suspect, it will also have "legs". "- danc at WhatsOniPhone.com   "dude -- your game rocks"  - Chris on an iPhone   "Poker Stacks lives up to this reputation…in spades. ...Extremely original gameplay ... Very nice graphics and animation ... Fantastic marriage between color matching and poker." - Doug at JustAnotherMobileMonday  ------------------------------------  Check Out Our Other Games Metal Tri-Peaks - Fast Solitaire Action Metal Euchre - Great Euchre Gameplay All IN POKER -  7 Poker Variations", "genre": ["Puzzle"], "metascore": 0, "critic_reviews": 0, "user_score": 0, "user_reviews": 0, "release_date": "2009-06-28", "images": ["https://www.metacritic.com/a/img/catalog/provider/6/12/6-1-120767-17.jpg", "https://www.metacritic.com/a/img/catalog/provider/6/12/6-1-120767-17.jpg"], "video": null, "video_thumbnail": null, "video_type": null, "sentiment": null, "must_play": false, "crew": null, "countries": ["North America"], "companies": ["Birdsoft LLC (Publisher)", "Birdsoft LLC (Developer)"], "platforms": ["iOS (iPhone/iPad)"], "rating": null}

To solve each puzzle, you must complete the number matrix using logic and memory by filling in the puzzle so the numbers follow a horizontal or vertical path from 1 to 81 (no diagonals). Each puzzle has a unique solution, and no math or guesswork is involved.  You can also compete with players around the world for the best time on each puzzle using our online leaderboard for an additional challenge!  The game comes over 150 puzzles that you can play immediately, and you will automatically receive new puzzle updates when either your iPhone or iPod Touch is connected to the Internet.  There are three levels of difficulty available, providing puzzles for both the Numbrix beginner or expert.  If you enjoy other puzzle games like Sudoku, Trism, Bejeweled, or Kakuro, you will love Numbrix!
